Aldehyde C was synthesized following  the reported procedure.1 NMR spectra  for the characterization of the products were  recorded on a Bruker 400 MHz spectrometer. In 1H NMR spectra chemical shift (¦Ä) values are reported  in ppm relative to the TMS (0.00 ppm) , as an internal standard in CDCl 3. Bruker ALPHA FTI R spectrometer was used for recording IR spectra. High resolution mass spectra were recorded on a Q -TOF instrument by electrospray ionization (ESI) technique.

Aldehyde A:  In a 100 mL flame dried double -neck round bottom flask 500 mg of 4 -bromobenzaldehyde (2.70 ¡Á 10-3 mol) and 920 mg (6.1 4 ¡Á 10-3 mol) of 3 -formylphenylboronic acid were taken in 50 mL THF and onto that 20 mL aqu eous solution of 700 mg (5.10  ¡Á 10-3 mol) K 2CO 3 was added. The resulting solution mixture was stirred under nitrogen atmosphere at room temperature for 10 minutes followed by addition of 80  mg ( 6. 92  ¡Á 10-5 mol) of Pd(PPh 3)4 and heated to 80 ¡ãC for 48h. After completion of the reaction THF was completely removed and the aqueous part was extracted with dichloromethane (50 mL ¡Á 3). Organ ic part was then dried over sodium sulphate and completely removed . The resulting  solid mass was purified by silica ElectronicSupplementaryMaterial(ESI)forChemComm.

Aldehyde B:  Aldehyde B was pre pared as pale yellow solid from 402 mg (2.00 ¡Á 10-3 mol) of 5 - bromosalicylaldehyde and 440 mg (2.93¡Á 10-3 mol) of 3 -formylphenylboronic acid, following the same synthetic protocol employed for aldehyde A. Isolated yield:  65 % ( 293 mg, 1.30¡Á 10-3 mol).  1H NMR (CDCl 3, 400MHz):  ¦Ä 7.14 (d, 1 H), 7.73 (dd, 2 H), 7.82 (m, 1H),  7.84 (s, 1 H), 7.96 (d, 2 H); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl 3): ¦Ä 119.1, 121.3, 127.5, 130.9, 132.2, 132.8 , 135 .7, 136.2 , 145.6, 162.3, 192. 2, 196.9 .

Cage A3X2II:  In a 8 mL glass vial 4 mL chloroform solutio n of 2.9 mg (2.00 ¡Á 10-5 mol) of amine X was added drop -wise slowly to the stirring solution of 6.3 mg (3.00 ¡Á 10-5 mol) of aldehyde A in 3 mL chloroform. The resulting solution mixture was kept for stirring at room temperature for an additional 24 h. Afte r completion of the reaction, solvent was reduced in volume and the product was predicated out  as white solid  by adding n-pentane.  Isolated yield = 92 %  (7.5 mg,  9.21 ¡Á 10-6 mol) . 1H NMR (CDCl 3, 400MHz): ¦Ä 2.78 -2.88 (m, 12H), 3.48 -3.68 (m,12H), 6.70 (br, 2H), 6.76 (d, 4H), 6.95 (d, 2H), 7.00 (s, 1H), 7.09 (d, 4H), 7.43 (d, 2H), 7.51 - 7.60 (m, 4H), 7.61 (s, 2H), 7.80 (d, 2H), 7.93 (d,1H), 7.93 (d, 3H), 8.13 (d, 2H), 8.21 (d,1H) ; 13C NMR (100 MHz , CDCl 3): 56.1, 56.3, 56.8, 57.1, 59.6, 60.1, 60.3, 60.6, 125.4, 125.6, 126.5, 126.7, 128.5, 128.8, 129.0, 129.5, 129.7, 129.9, 130.2, 135.7, 135.9, 137.9  (two peaks) , 140.3, 140.4, 141.4, 161.1, 161.3, 161.8, 162.4; ESI -HRMS (CHCl 3/CH 3CN, 1:1 ), m/z [M+H]+ 815.4729 (calculated 815. 4549);  FTIR (cm-1) ¦Í: 2890, 2820, 2802, 1641, 1606, 1441, 1329, 1287, 1064, 1034, 910, 833, 793, 692.  Cage B3X2II: This cage was synthesized as yellow solid, from 6.8 mg (3.00 ¡Á 10-5 mol) of aldehyde B and 2.9 mg  (2.00 ¡Á 10-5 mol) of amine X following the same procedure as  employed for the cage A3X2II. Obtained solid sample was re -dissolved in chloroform and crystallized by slow vapor diffusion of n -pentane to get pure cage B3X2II. Isolated yield = 7 5 % (6.5 mg,  7.50 ¡Á 10-6 mol) . 1H NMR (CDCl 3, 400MHz): ¦Ä 2.80 -2.89 (m,  12H) , 3.51 -3.69 (m, 12H), 6.68 - 6.72 (m, 5H), 6.95 (d, 2H), 7.05 -7.07 (m, 6H ), 7.13 (d, 2H), 7.33 (d, 2H), 7.51 (s, 1H), 7.59(s, 2H), 7.64 (dd, 2H), 7.72 (dd, 1H) , 7.89 (s , 2H), 7.98 (br, 2H) ; 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl 3): 55.8, 56.2 (two peaks), 56.8 ,  57.9, 58. 1, 59.5, 60.0, 118.2, 118.5, 119.0, 125.5, 125.7, 128.2, 128.7,129.8, 129.9, 130.0, 130.7, 131.0,134.2, 134.3, 140.8, 141.0, 161.8, 162.1, 162.3, 162.6, 165.5, 165.6.

The selective formation of a single isomer of a [3+2] self-assembledorganic cage from a reaction mixture of an unsymmetrical aldehydeand a flexible amine is discussed. The experimental and theoreticalfindings suggest that in such a process, the geometric features ofthe aldehyde play a key role.

For an in-depth understanding of this subject, we thought tomonitor ( in situ )t h er e a c t i o nb e t w e e na l d e h y d e Band amine Xina step-wise fashion. Therefore 3 equiv. of Bwas first treated with1e q u i v .o fa m i n e Xin CDCl3at room temperature for 24 hours(Scheme 2). The1H NMR spectrum (Fig. S16, ESI ?)o ft h er e a c t i o nmixture after the said time period suggested that the formyl groupadjacent to the hydroxyl moiety ( meta -aldehyde) selectively reactedwith the amine to form the corresponding [3+1] assembly (imine¨Caldehyde compound). X-ray crystallographic analysis of the assem-bly unambiguously justified thi s observation. The preference ofthe amine for the meta -aldehyde could be attributed to the higherreactivity of the formyl group and the thermodynamic stability ofthe resulting assembly, owing to the intramolecular hydrogenbonding.

5bWhen the resulting [3+1] assembly was further allowedto react with 1 more equiv. of amine Xin CDCl 3at roomtemperature, we observed again the formation of a mixture ofisomers ( IandII) rather than the selective formation of isomer I(which was expected) (Scheme 2), as evidenced by the protonNMR spectra (Fig. S17, ESI ?). These experimental findingsclearly suggest that, though intramolecular hydrogen bondinghas an important role to play during the self-assembly process,the selective formation of only one isomer at room temperatureis not possible in the case of aldehyde B.

12It is well-known that a self-selection process can be influencedby external stimuli, such as by the reaction temperature.13Therefore, in order to investigate the role of temperature onScheme 1 Schematic presentation of possible isomeric cages upon the[3+2] self-assembly of an unsymmetrical aldehyde Aand a flexible amine X.

Colourless rod-shaped single crystals of cage A3X2II(super-script represent the isomer) were grown from a CHCl 3¨CCH 3CNsolution by slow evaporation, and crystallized in triclinic crystalsystem with the space group P%1. The crystallization protocol ofthe cage B3X2IIhas already been mentioned. This cage wasfound to crystallize in monoclinic crystal system with the P21/cspace group. Yellow block-shaped single crystals of the [3+1]imine¨Caldehyde compound B3XIwere crystallized from thereaction mixture by the slow evaporation of CHCl 3in a trigonalcrystal system with the space group P%3c1. In a similar fashion,crystals of [3+1] assembly C3XIwere also obtained. In conclusion, we have explored the possibility of usingunsymmetrical building units for constructing organic cagesusing dynamic covalent chemistry. Interestingly, the self-selectionof one isomeric cage out of two equally probable isomeric cageswas successfully achieved. Such a process is well supported byvarious spectroscopic techniques. The experimental findingssuggested that the formation of a selective isomer of a [3+2]oligoimine cage from a reaction mixture of an unsymmetricalaldehyde and a flexible amine depends on the shape and size ofthe building aldehyde. Theoretical calculations suggested thatthe energy di?erence between the isomers was the governingfactor in isomer selection, which correlates pretty well with thegeometric shape and size of the reacting aldehyde.
